rationales.self_direction: She said yes to Marcus's mom's custom homework request before even finishing the email, and she deflected her own mother's concern rather than acknowledging her own needs.
rationales.conformity: She agreed to a fourth family's custom homework request without pushback, meeting every parent's expectation regardless of the burden on herself.
rationales.benevolence: She spent Sunday lesson planning and creating extra worksheets for struggling students, and reassured her mom not to worry about her.

rationales.self_direction: She made an intentional pedagogical choice to respond to Aiden's wrong answer with a follow-up question that let him get partway there, creating a safe space on her own terms.
rationales.benevolence: She recognized Aiden's withdrawal since his parents' split and celebrated his first hand-raise, seeing it as evidence he trusted the room enough to risk being wrong.

rationales.self_direction: She wanted to tell Mrs. Patterson her daughter is at grade level but didn't, suppressing her professional judgment and spending her evening creating an unnecessary enrichment packet.
rationales.power: She's scared Mrs. Patterson will go to Principal Davis, so she capitulates to the loudest parent rather than asserting her professional authority.
rationales.conformity: She nodded through twenty minutes of demands and agreed to differentiated assignments she doesn't think are needed, avoiding any conflict.
rationales.benevolence: She acknowledges eight kids reading below benchmark need her attention more, but she's prioritizing the loud parent's request over the students who actually need help.

rationales.self_direction: She didn't voice her frustration about the new reading assessment mandate that costs two instruction days, choosing silence along with everyone else.
rationales.achievement: Losing two instruction days to an assessment mandate undermines her classroom goals, yet she accepts it passively with Lisa noting 'there's no point fighting it.'
rationales.conformity: She nodded along with the mandate like everyone else at the staff meeting, going along with the institutional decision without protest.

rationales.self_direction: She heard herself saying 'sure' to the parent workshop without choosing to, unable to say no when everyone looked at her expectantly.
rationales.power: Principal Davis publicly assigned her a task by singling her out, and she had no ability to resist the social pressure of the room.
rationales.security: She's overextended with bus duty, book club, and now the parent workshop, and her mother's advice about empty cups signals her wellbeing is under threat.
rationales.conformity: She took on coordinating the parent workshop because the principal pointed to her and everyone smiled, conforming to the expectation that she's the one who always says yes.

rationales.hedonism: Jaylen's crayon drawing of her, him, and the classroom hamster brought her genuine joy -- 'Some days that's enough. Today it was.'
rationales.benevolence: She keeps all the students' drawings in her desk drawer, treasuring the relationship with a child who calls her his favorite teacher ever.

rationales.security: She reassures herself with routine -- 'This is fine. This is just September. It always gets easier by October' -- seeking comfort in the predictable cycle of the school year.
rationales.benevolence: She's planning how to carefully tell the Millers about their son's potential evaluation need, spending mental energy to protect their feelings while advocating for the child.

rationales.self_direction: She 'backpedaled so fast' when Eli's dad looked hurt, abandoning her professional assessment and telling him his son is 'doing great actually' when she knows otherwise.
rationales.achievement: She told every parent their kid was making progress even when she had concerns, giving up on her pedagogical goals to avoid difficult conversations.
rationales.power: She couldn't hold her ground with Eli's dad, immediately retreating from her position when he pushed back, showing helplessness in asserting her expertise.
rationales.conformity: She smiled through four hours of back-to-back conferences and told every parent what they wanted to hear, maintaining harmony at the expense of honesty.
rationales.benevolence: She acknowledges Eli needs help but staying quiet means he won't get support until someone else raises it -- her conflict avoidance directly harms a student she's responsible for.

rationales.stimulation: She made her first social plan in three weeks that isn't work-related, breaking out of her all-consuming routine by saying yes to brunch with Lisa.
rationales.hedonism: A Saturday that 'felt like a Saturday for once' -- she caught up on tasks, went for a walk, and made a plan for enjoyment without work pressure.
rationales.security: The calm, structured Saturday of catching up on emails, planning lessons, and walking the neighborhood provided a sense of normalcy and rest.
rationales.benevolence: She said yes to brunch with Lisa, investing in a friendship she's been neglecting amid the demands of school.

rationales.self_direction: When Lisa told her she doesn't have to be everything for everyone, she changed the subject, unable to confront whether she wants to change her pattern of self-sacrifice.
rationales.conformity: She gave Lisa 'the usual answer -- busy, tired, fine' and defines herself through meeting others' expectations, saying 'the kids need someone who shows up, the parents need someone who listens.'
rationales.tradition: She frames her self-sacrificing role as 'maybe that's just what teaching is, maybe that's just what I am,' accepting it as an identity she inherited rather than chose.
rationales.benevolence: Despite everything, she cared about having a real friend conversation with Lisa and valued the brunch as 'normal friend things' -- showing and receiving care.
